description.narrative: The present project responds to Decision GC 27/12 on Chemicals and Waste Management where UNEP has been requested “to develop a global outlook of challenges, trends and policies…”. The project therefore aims to develop a “Global Waste Management Outlook” (GWMO) through a multi-stakeholder consultative process. The GWMO will be published in the third quarter of 2015. The overarching objective of the GWMO project is to provide an authoritative overview and analysis of policy instruments and financing models for waste management. The Outlook would complement and add value to existing publications by assembling standardized policy indicators to allow better comparative analyses of the state of waste management, particularly in relation to policy and resource gaps. The lead partners in the project are the International Environmental Technology Centre (IETC) of the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and the International Solid Waste Association (ISWA) within the framework of their cooperation agreement established in December 2012.The GWMO will be complimented with Regional Waste Management Outlooks (RWMOs). Preparations for the development of the RWMOs will start early 2015. During the XIX Meeting of the Forum of Ministers of Environment of Latin America and the Caribbean (Los Cabos, Mexico, 11-14 March 2014), LAC countries requested to UNEP to “develop a regional outlook on the main challenges, trends and policies related to integrated waste avoidance, minimization and management, so that it can be used as guidance for the design and implementation of national policies, plans, programmes and projects”. Additionally the Interstate Commission on Sustainable Development (ICSD) in Central Asia requested IETC’s assistance to put together a regional outlook for their region, and Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) have asked for the development of the Regional Outlook for Asia.The results and outcomes of this project will be a relevant input to those in a position to develop and deploy policy instruments, allocate funding and facilitate effective waste management.
